vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/3827bffc-3760-4875-af61-0ef75a718892">WORKS COUNCILS</keyword>         <topcClas>General - Employment and labour</topcClas>         <topcClas>Social indicators and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>European Company Survey</i> (ECS) is a large-scale representative survey among establishments in the European Union (EU) and is carried out every four years. The ECS examines a range of issues, such as working time, work-life balance, and the development of social dialogue in companies. The survey series aims to map working time policies and practices at the level of the establishment in the EU, to survey the views of the different actors at establishment level on these policies and practices, and to provide policy makers with a picture of the main issues and developments in the field.<br> <br> The first company survey in the series was known as the <i>Establishment Survey on Working Time and Work-Life Balance, 2004-2005</i> (available from the UK Data Archive under SN 5655). The second survey has taken on the new title of the <i>European Company Survey, 2009</i> (available from the Archive under SN 6568).<br> <br> Further information about the ECS can be found on the <a href="http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/companysurvey/index.htm" title ="Eurofound">Eurofound</a> ECS survey web pages.<br> </abstract>       <abstract>The <i>European Company Survey, 2009</i> is the second Europe-wide survey of establishments carried out by Eurofound. The 2009 survey focuses on two major themes: flexibility practices in companies and employee participation at the workplace. The 2009 survey covered 30 countries, including the 27 EU Member States, as well as the three candidate countries of Turkey, Macedonia and Croatia. The interviews were carried out in establishments with 10 or more employees, both in the private and public sectors.<br> <br> Further information including findings from the survey can be found on the Eurofound  <a href="http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/surveys/companysurvey/2009/index.htm" title ="ECS 2009">ECS 2009</a> web pages.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Two questionnaires were fielded for the ECS 2009. From each company the manager responsible for human resources was interviewed, and where available, an interview was conducted with an employee representative.<br> <br> Survey respondents were asked questions on the following specific themes:<ul><li>working time flexibility</li><li>human resources practices</li><li>variable pay and financial participation schemes</li><li>workplace social dialogue</li><li>company performance</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2009-01-01T00:00:00Z">January 2009</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2009-05-01T00:00:00Z">May 2009</collDate>         <nation>Austria</nation>         <nation>Belgium</nation>         <nation>Bulgaria</nation>         <nation>Croatia</nation>         <nation>Cyprus</nation>         <nation>Czech Republic</nation>         <nation>Denmark</nation>         <nation>Estonia</nation>         <nation>Finland</nation>         <nation>France</nation>         <nation>Germany (October 1990-)</nation>         <nation>Greece</nation>         <nation>Hungary</nation>         <nation>Ireland</nation>         <nation>Italy</nation>         <nation>Latvia</nation>         <nation>Lithuania</nation>         <nation>Luxembourg</nation>         <nation>Macedonia</nation>         <nation>Malta</nation>         <nation>Netherlands</nation>         <nation>Poland</nation>         <nation>Portugal</nation>         <nation>Romania</nation>         <nation>Slovakia</nation>         <nation>Slovenia</nation>         <nation>Spain</nation>         <nation>Sweden</nation>         <nation>Turkey</nation>         <nation>United Kingdom</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Institutions/organisations</anlyUnit>         <universe>Cross-national; National</universe>         <universe>Managers and employees from establishments based in the EU, with 10 or more employees</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Further surveys are planned to be carried out every 4-5 years..</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>TNS Infratest Sozialforschung (Munich)</dataCollector>         <sampProc>One-stage stratified or systematic random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>27,160 (see documentation for country specific details)</deviat>         <collMode>Telephone interview</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Standard conditions of access</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about usage. (2011) 'Does the global economy mean more sweat? Trade, investment, migration and working hours in Europe', <i>Socio-Economic Review</i>, 9(4), pp.699-727. Retrieved January 3rd, 2012 from <a href="http://archive-ouverte.unige.ch/vital/access/manager/Repository/unige:17749" title="Does the global economy mean more sweat? Trade, investment, migration and working hours in Europe">http://archive-ouverte.unige.ch/vital/access/manager/Repository/unige:17749</a><br> <br> van den Berg, A. and Grift, Y. (2012) 'De economische effecten van medezeggenschap in de publieke sector' in H. Hartmann (ed.) <i>OR en invloed</i>, Alphen aan den Rijn: Kluwer, pp.21-38. ISBN 90-6500-168-9. (Dutch language: in translation this means 'the economic effects of codetermination in the public sector'. It deals with the role of Dutch works councils. The authors note that, to the best of their knowledge, the effects of public sector works councils have hardly (if ever) been studied empirically, either in the Netherlands or elsewhere.)<br> <br> Wi\ufffd\ufffd, Tobias (2014) 'Betriebliche Familienpolitik: \ufffd\ufffdsterreich im europ\ufffd\ufffdischen Vergleich' [Occupational family policy: Austria in comparison with European countries], <I>Kontraste</I>, 08/2014, pp.18-32.<br></relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English and other European languages</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
